questions.question_text:
You have 50 Microsoft Sentinel workspaces.

You need to view all the incidents from all the workspaces on a single page in the Azure portal. The solution must minimize administrative effort.

Which page should you use in the Azure portal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Correct answer is A) Microsoft Sentinel | Incidents, which allows you to view all incidents from all LA workspaces.

comments.content: The "Microsoft Sentinel" page in the Azure portal provides a centralized view across all your Sentinel workspaces within a given Azure tenant. This includes the ability to view incidents from all workspaces on a single page using the Incidents view within the main Sentinel landing page. This is specifically designed for cross-workspace management and minimizes administrative effort.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
All answers are kind of strange, but I would go with "C", because you need to select multiple workspaces and then click on "View Incidents". This all happens on the entry portal page to Microsoft Sentinel. So it is "C"

Official documentation about the right answer which is MS Sentinel- Incidents 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/sentinel/extend-sentinel-across-workspaces-tenants#manage-incidents-on-multiple-workspaces

Selected Answer: A
Entering multiple workspace view
When you open Microsoft Sentinel, you are presented with a list of all the workspaces to which you have access rights, across all selected tenants and subscriptions. To the left of each workspace name is a checkbox. Selecting the name of a single workspace will bring you into that workspace. To choose multiple workspaces, select all the corresponding checkboxes, and then select the View incidents button at the top of the page.

Overview -

Adatum Corporation is a United States-based financial services company that has regional offices in New York, Chicago, and San Francisco.


Existing Environment -


Identity Environment -

The on-premises network contains an Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) forest named corp.adatum.com that syncs with an Azure AD tenant named adatum.com. All user and group management tasks are performed in corp.adatum.com. The corp.adatum.com domain contains a group named Group1 that syncs with adatum.com.


Licensing Status -

All the users at Adatum are assigned a Microsoft 365 ES license and an Azure Active Directory Premium P2 license.


Cloud Environment -

The cloud environment contains a Microsoft 365 subscription, an Azure subscription linked to the adatum.com tenant, and the resources shown in the following table.

//IMG//



On-premises Environment -

The on-premises network contains the resources shown in the following table.

//IMG//



Requirements -


Planned changes -

Adatum plans to perform the following changes:

• Implement a query named rulequery1 that will include the following KQL query.

//IMG//


• Implement a Microsoft Sentinel scheduled rule that generates incidents based on rulequery1.

Microsoft Defender for Cloud Requirements

Adatum identifies the following Microsoft Defender for Cloud requirements:

• The members of Group1 must be able to enable Defender for Cloud plans and apply regulatory compliance initiatives.
• Microsoft Defender for Servers Plan 2 must be enabled on all the Azure virtual machines.
• Server2 must be excluded from agentless scanning.


Microsoft Sentinel Requirements -

Adatum identifies the following Microsoft Sentinel requirements:

• Implement an Advanced Security Information Model (ASIM) query that will return a count of DNS requests that results in an NXDOMAIN response from Infoblox1.
• Ensure that multiple alerts generated by rulequery1 in response to a single user launching Azure Cloud Shell multiple times are consolidated as a single incident.
• Implement the Windows Security Events via AMA connector for Microsoft Sentinel and configure it to monitor the Security event log of Server1.
• Ensure that incidents generated by rulequery1 are closed automatically if Azure Cloud Shell is launched by the company’s SecOps team.
• Implement a custom Microsoft Sentinel workbook named Workbook1 that will include a query to dynamically retrieve data from Webapp1.
• Implement a Microsoft Sentinel near-real-time (NRT) analytics rule that detects sign-ins to a designated break glass account.
• Ensure that HuntingQuery1 runs automatically when the Hunting page of Microsoft Sentinel in the Azure portal is accessed.
• Ensure that higher than normal volumes of password resets for corp.adatum.com user accounts are detected.
• Minimize the overhead associated with queries that use ASIM parsers.
• Ensure that the Group1 members can create and edit playbooks.
• Use built-in ASIM parsers whenever possible.


Business Requirements -

Adatum identifies the following business requirements:

• Follow the principle of least privilege whenever possible.
• Minimize administrative effort whenever possible.


You need to implement the scheduled rule for incident generation based on rulequery1.

What should you configure first?

discussion.content: I hate this long case study

Selected Answer: B
From Microsoft documentation after completing query: Alert enrichment
Use the Entity mapping configuration section to map parameters from your query results to Microsoft Sentinel-recognized entities. Entities enrich the rules' output (alerts and incidents) with essential information that serves as the building blocks of any investigative processes and remedial actions that follow. They are also the criteria by which you can group alerts together into incidents in the Incident settings tab.

Selected Answer: D
I honestly think I would go with D. When you ceate an alert that is the first tab you enter where you input alert title, severity, description, and tactics. Then you would set your rule logic where your query, mappings, etc are. The only issue is it's called 'general' and not alert details. I can understand B but I create a lot of alerts for work and would never start on entity mappings

comments.content: I take it back. Alert details is in the alert enhancment pane. So it would indeed be B. Damn these questions that require you to know every pane name lol. Been doing this for 6 years and still missed this question.

discussion.content:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/sentinel/create-analytics-rules?tabs=azure-portal
In Analytic rules configuration wizard right under the analytics KQL query, you have, and in that order: Entity Mapping, Custom details, Alert Details, Query Scheduling then only events grouping... B is therefore the most probable answer.

Answer is C

To implement a Microsoft Sentinel scheduled rule for incident generation based on rulequery1, and considering that multiple alerts generated by the query in response to a single user launching Azure Cloud Shell multiple times need to be consolidated into a single incident, the key focus should be on event grouping.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A it is

Selected Answer: A
I'll vote for A. 
Be careful with the wording a tricky question & seems like having multiple correct answers. 
In Sentinel it is either called as "automation rule/s" or "Sentinel automation rule/s". There is no such thing like Azure automation rule. Perhaps Microsoft is testing your terminology knowledge here it seems. :D

You can also close an inc, using a playbook, in this case it must use "Incident" as a trigger.

You can create an automation rule & use the "actions" option to close an incident. Remember you can create an automation rule under the "automated response" section of an analytics rule as well!
If you want to use a playbook as an action in your automation rule, you must make sure your logic app with relevant trigger already exists, else it will not be shown in the dropdown menu.

I believe the answer here is C. Particularly this line here from Microsoft: "Automatically tag, assign, or close incidents without a playbook".

Link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/sentinel/automation/automation

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/sentinel/playbook-triggers-actions#microsoft-sentinel-triggers-summary
